TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi sealed beforefieldinit OracleNumber extends System.ValueType implements class System.Data.SqlTypes.INullable, class System.IComparable
Public Structure OracleNumber Implements IComparable, INullable
public value class OracleNumber : IComparable, System::Data::SqlTypes::INullable

Docs.summary: Represents a fixed precision and scale numeric value between -10 27 -1 and 10 27 -1 to be stored in or retrieved from a database.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To obtain an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> object, call the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataReader.GetOracleNumber%2A> method.
Oracle numeric data types can store up to 27 decimal digits of precision. When converting Oracle numeric values to common language runtime data types, the Oracle value might be too large. Conversely, when converting a numeric value of a common language runtime data types to an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber>, the numeric value may be either too large or too high precision for the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber>. Either of these cases will cause an Oracle ORA-22053 overflow error. If your Oracle database might contain large values, you should use the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> data type. You can then convert to the common language runtime data type explicitly, and catch or handle any errors.

Docs.summary: Compares this instance of the structure to the supplied object and returns an indication of their relative values.
Docs.returns:
A signed number indicating the relative values of the instance and the object.
Return Value
Condition
Less than zero
This instance is less than the object.
Zero
This instance is the same as the object.
Greater than zero
This instance is greater than the object, or the object is a null reference ( in Visual Basic)

Docs.summary: A constant representing the maximum value of an structure.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The value of this constant is 9.9999999999999999999999999999999999999E+125. This number has a greater precision than what a common language run-time `Double` data type can contain. If you attempt to store this value in a `Double`, the value is rounded up to 1E+126. The maximum `Double` value that can be used in the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> (Double) constructor is: 9.99999999999999E+125.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example creates an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> and converts it to an <xref:System.Int32>.
```csharp //Create OracleNumber and cast it to an Int32. OracleNumber n = new OracleNumber(42); Int32 i = (Int32)n; Console.WriteLine(i); ```
```vb 'Create OracleNumber and cast it to an Int32. Dim n As OracleNumber = New OracleNumber(42) Dim i As Int32 = (Int32)n Console.WriteLine(i)) ```

Docs.param: The decimal position to which the number will be truncated.
Docs.summary: Truncates the specified structure's value to the desired position.
Docs.returns: A structure with its truncated to the specified .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Supply a negative value for the `position` parameter in order to truncate the value to the corresponding position to the left of the decimal point.
